Dual Class Documentation

  • Author: Alexandr Prucha

  • Project: Autodifferentiation with Dual Numbers

  • Version: 0.1

  • Python Version: 3.12.3

  • License: MIT

Welcome to the documentation for the Dual Autodifferentiation Package for Cython! This package provides utilities for automatic differentiation.

Installation

To install the package, download the wheel for your python version and run the following command in the Python shell:

pip install ./dual_autodiff_x-0.0.1b2-cp311-cp311-manylinux_2_17_x86_64.manylinux2014_x86_64.whl

for python3.11 or:

pip install ./dual_autodiff_x-0.0.1b2-cp310-cp310-manylinux_2_17_x86_64.manylinux2014_x86_64.whl

for python3.10.

Note: Separate installations of numpy and pytest are required.

In this section we provide detailed documentation for the modules and classes in the dual_autodiff_x package.

Dual Class Overview

The class Dual_x generates Dual numbers from pairs of inputs. It also provides methods for performing basic calculations, and evaluating elementary functions. Like its equivalen Dual class in the pure Python version of the package, Dual_x dynamically type-checks inputs and handles them appropriately as scalars or arrays. For faster computation, the package also includes class Dual_x_array for specific use on arrays, that does statically declares the variables as array-like. In terms of syntax, Dual_x and Dual_x_array are otherwise identical, so we only include Dual_x here.

class Dual_x

Bases: object

A class representing dual numbers for automatic differentiation.

real

The real part of the dual number. This can be a scalar (float or int) or an array-like object (e.g., list, tuple, numpy.ndarray).

Type:

float, int, or array-like

dual

The dual part of the dual number. This can be a scalar (float or int) or an array-like object (e.g., list, tuple, numpy.ndarray).

Type:

float, int, or array-like

Note

For mathematical operations like sine, cosine, and logarithm, the real and dual parts of the output are evaluated according to the following formula:

\[f(a + b\epsilon) = f(a) + f'(a)b\epsilon\]

This formula describes how dual numbers are processed through a given mathematical function (f).

__add__()

Add two Dual_x numbers.

Operator:

Uses the \(+\) operator.

Returns:

A new Dual_x number representing their sum.

Return type:

Dual_x

__mul__()

Multiply two Dual_x numbers.

Operator:

Uses the \(*\) operator.

Returns:

A new Dual_x number representing the product \((a + b\epsilon)(c + d\epsilon)\). The real part of the product output is simply the product of the real parts of the arguments \(ab\). The dual part of the output is the term that is first order in \(\epsilon\) \((ad + bc)\).

Return type:

Dual_x

__pow__()

Raise a Dual_x number to a power.

Operator:

Uses the \(**\) operator.

Parameters:

exponent (float, int) – The exponent to raise the Dual_x number to. Must be a real number.

Returns:

A new Dual_x number raised to the power of the exponent.

Return type:

Dual_x

__sub__()

Subtract one Dual_x number from another.

Operator:

Uses the \(-\) operator.

Returns:

A new Dual_x number representing the difference.

Return type:

Dual_x

Note

For addition and subtraction, the real and dual parts are added or subtracted separately.

cos()

Compute the cosine of the Dual_x number.

Returns:

A new Dual_x number representing the cosine.

Return type:

Dual_x

dual
exp()

Compute the exponential of the Dual_x number.

Returns:

A new Dual_x number representing the exponential.

Return type:

Dual_x

log()

Compute the natural logarithm of the Dual_x number.

Raises:

  • ValueError – If the real part is less than or equal to zero.

  • ValueError – If the real part is less than 1e-10.

  • RuntimeWarning – If the real part is close to zero within 1e-6 but larger than 1e-10.

real
sin()

Compute the sine of the Dual_x number.

Returns:

A new Dual_x number representing the sine.

Return type:

Dual_x

tan()

Compute the tangent of the Dual number.

Returns:

A new Dual number representing the tangent.

Return type:

Dual

Raises:

  • ValueError – If the real part is within 1e-10 of (π/2 + nπ), where tangent is undefined.

  • RuntimeWarning – If the real part is close to (π/2 + nπ) by less than 1e-6, which may cause numerical instability.
